Line 96: Line 96:
[[Ayman Nour]], the founder of the liberal opposition [[El-Ghad Party]], tweeted that his son was taken by an unmarked car.<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks">{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/26/egypt-protests|title=Egypt protests: 'We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks'|publisher=The Guardian|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Security forces arrested ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' reporter Jack Shenker in Cairo, who secretly recorded his subsequent journey in a police van. After stopping near a government security headquarters outside the city, a policeman searched for Ayman Nour's son, however, the detainees overpowered him and escaped.<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks"/>
[[Ayman Nour]], the founder of the liberal opposition [[El-Ghad Party]], tweeted that his son was taken by an unmarked car.<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks">{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/26/egypt-protests|title=Egypt protests: 'We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks'|publisher=The Guardian|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Security forces arrested ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' reporter Jack Shenker in Cairo, who secretly recorded his subsequent journey in a police van. After stopping near a government security headquarters outside the city, a policeman searched for Ayman Nour's son, however, the detainees overpowered him and escaped.<ref name="We ran a gauntlet of officers beating us with sticks"/>
â   â
===Suez ===
  â
The city of Suez has seen the most violence of the protests thus far, with three of the seven documented deaths. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, though confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com"/> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], pointing to the Tunisian city around which that nation's 2011 protests centered.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
 
=== 25 January â Day of Anger ===
=== 25 January â Day of Anger ===
Line 185: Line 182:
== Major issues ==
== Major issues ==
  +
=== Suez ===
  +
The city of Suez has seen the most violence of the protests thus far, with three of the seven documented deaths. Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, though confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com"/> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], pointing to the Tunisian city around which that nation's 2011 protests centered.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
  +
===Internal responses===
===Internal responses===
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] called for ousting the regime, as in Tunisia.<ref name="Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt"/> He said he was "proud of the protesters" and proud of the military, who by 29 January were the only state force on the streets of Cairo, with police nowhere to be seen. There were numerous individual public displays of affection and respect for soldiers manning positions on the streets.<ref>Al Jazeera English, TV report, 29 January, 12.00 GMT</ref>
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] called for ousting the regime, as in Tunisia.<ref name="Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt"/> He said he was "proud of the protesters" and proud of the military, who by 29 January were the only state force on the streets of Cairo, with police nowhere to be seen. There were numerous individual public displays of affection and respect for soldiers manning positions on the streets.<ref>Al Jazeera English, TV report, 29 January, 12.00 GMT</ref>
